pending_diagnosis: DIAGNOSIS: Acute Ethylene Glycol Poisoning (Antifreeze Toxicity) THE SMOKING GUN: The crucial information was the presence of an unmeasured osmole. While the initial osmolality (295 mOsm/kg) was near the reference range, the calculated osmolality (2Na + Gluc/18 + BUN/2.8) was 278 mOsm/kg. This resulted in an Osmolal Gap of 17—suggesting a hidden toxic alcohol. However, the definitive finding, retrospectively sought, was the analysis of the first urine sample before anuria set in: microscopy revealed copious amounts of calcium oxalate monohydrate crystals, often described as "Envelope" or "Dumbbell" shaped crystals, providing the visual proof of nephrotoxicity from oxalic acid. PATHOPHYSIOLOGY: Ethylene glycol (EG) is metabolized in the liver by alcohol dehydrogenase (ADH). The resulting metabolites are the source of toxicity: 1. Glycolic Acid: Rapidly accumulates and causes the severe, refractory high anion gap metabolic acidosis (pH 6.98). This metabolite is also primarily responsible for the acute CNS dysfunction. 2. Oxalic Acid: Is the final toxic metabolite. It rapidly binds with circulating calcium, leading to profound hypocalcemia (contributing to cardiac instability) and precipitates as insoluble calcium oxalate crystals. These crystals deposit directly in the renal tubules, causing severe acute tubular necrosis (ATN), leading to the observed anuria and catastrophic acute kidney injury. The basal ganglia hyperintensities on MRI are highly characteristic of EG or methanol toxicity due to direct cytotoxic effects of the acid metabolites. Immediate treatment involves competitive inhibition of ADH using Fomepizole or high-dose IV ethanol, alongside aggressive hemodialysis to clear the toxic acids.
